'''Cyrus''' ([[Persian language|Persian]]: ⁄©Ÿàÿ±Ÿàÿ¥) is a male given name. Etymologically it is the [[English language|English]] transliteration of the [[Persian language|Persian]] name ''[[Kourosh]]'' (⁄©Ÿàÿ±Ÿàÿ¥). It is the given name of a number of [[Persian Kings|Persian kings]]. Most notably it refers to [[Cyrus the Great]]. Cyrus is also the name of [[Cyrus I of Anshan]] (ca. 650 BC), King of Persia the grandfather of Cyrus the Great; and [[Cyrus the Younger]] (died 401 BC), brother to the Persian King [[Artaxerxes II of Persia]].
== Etymology ==
Cyrus, as a word in English, is the [[Latin]]ized form of the [[Greek language|Greek]] [[wikt:Œö·ø¶œÅŒøœÇ|Œö·ø¶œÅŒøœÇ]], ''K»≥ros'', from [[Old Persian]] {{lang|peo|[[wikt:êé§êé¢êéΩêé¢êèÅ|êé§êé¢êéΩêé¢êèÅ]]}} ''K≈´ru≈°''.<ref name=cyrusthename>{{harv|Schmitt|1996a}}</ref> According to the inscriptions the name is reflected in [[Elamite]] ''Kura≈°'', [[Akkadian language|Babylonian]] ''Ku(r)-ra≈°/-ra-√°≈°'' and [[Imperial Aramaic]] ''kwr≈°''. The modern Persian form of the name is [[Kourosh]].
The etymology of Cyrus has been and continues to be a topic of discussion amongst [[historians]], [[linguists]], and scholars of [[Iranology]]. The Old Persian name "kuru≈°" has been interpreted in various forms from "the Sun", "like Sun", "young", "hero" to "humiliator of the enemy in verbal contest" and the Elamite "kura≈°" has been translated as one "who bestows care".
The name has appeared on many monuments and inscriptions in Old Persian.<ref name=chicyrus>{{harv|Gershevitch|1985|pp=392‚Äì5}}</ref> There is also the record of a small inscription in Morghab (southwestern Iran) on which there is the sentence (''adam k≈´ru≈° x≈°ƒÅya∆üiya haxƒÅmani≈°iya'') in [[Old Persian]] meaning (''I am Cyrus the [[Achaemenian#Achaemenid kings and leaders|Achaemenian]] King'').<ref name=murghabinscription>{{harv|Tolman|1908|p=55}}</ref> After a questionable<ref name=kurusname>{{harv|Tolam|1908|p=82}}</ref> proposal by the German linguist F. H. Weissbach that [[Darius the Great]] was the first to inscribe in [[Old Persian|Persian]], it had previously been concluded by some scholars that the inscription in Morghab refers to Cyrus the Younger. This proposal was the result of a false interpretation of a passage in paragraph 70 of [[Behistun inscription]] by Darius the Great.<ref>{{harv|Gershevitch|1985|p=395}}</ref> Based on many arguments,<ref>{{harv|Ghirshman|1965|p=246}}</ref> the accepted theory among modern scholars is that the inscription does belong to Cyrus the Great.<ref name=cyrustheyounger>{{harv|Schmitt|1996b}}</ref>
There are interpretations of name of Cyrus by classical authors identifying with or referring to the Persian word for ‚ÄúSun‚Äù. The Historian [[Plutarch]] (46 - 120) states that "the sun, which, in the [[Old Persian|Persian language]], is called Cyrus".<ref>[[Plutarch]], [http://classics.mit.edu/Plutarch/artaxerx.html ''Artoxerxes''] in [[Parallel Lives|(Parallel lives)]]</ref> Also the Physician [[Ctesias]] who served in the court of the Persian king [[Artaxerxes II of Persia]] writes in his book ''Persica'' as summarized by [[Photios I of Constantinople#Writings|Photios]] that the name Cyrus is from Persian word "Khur" (the sun).<ref>Epitome of [[Ctesias]]' Persica [http://www.livius.org/ct-cz/ctesias/photius_persica3.html 52].</ref> These are, however, not accepted by modern scholars.<ref name=cyrusthename/>
Regarding the etymology of Old Persian ''kuru≈°'', linguists have proposed various etymologies based on Iranian languages as well as non-[[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] ones.<ref name=Tavernier>{{harv|Tavernier|2007|p=528}}</ref> According to Tavernier, the name ''kura≈°'', attested in Elamite texts, is likely "the original form" as there is no Elamite or Babylonian spelling ''ku-ru-u≈°'' in the transcriptions of Old Persian ''ku-u-r(u)-u-≈°''. That is, according to Tavernier, ''kura≈°'' is an Elamite name and means "to bestow care".<ref name=Tavernier/> Others, such as Schmitt, Hoffmann maintain that the Persian ''Kuru≈°'', which according to Skalmowsky, may be connected to (or a borrowing from) the [[Proto-Indo-European language|IE]] ''K√∫ru-'' from [[Old Indic]] can give an etymology of the Elamite ''kura≈°''.<ref name=cyrusthename/><ref name=Tavernier/> In this regard the Old Persian ''kuru≈°'' is considered with the following etymologies: One proposal is discussed by the linguist [[Janos Harmatta]] that refers to the common Iranian root "kur-" (be born) of many words in Old, middle, and new [[Iranian languages]] (e.g. [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]]). Accordingly, the name K≈´ru≈° means "young, youth...".<ref name=harmatta>{{harv|Harmatta|1971|pp=5‚Äì6}}</ref> Other Iranian etymologies have been proposed. The Indian proposal of Skalmowsky goes down to "to do, accomplish". Another theory is the suggestion of [[Karl Hoffmann (German historian)|Karl Hoffmann]] that ''kuru≈°'' goes down to a ''-ru'' derivation from the IE root ''*(s)kau'' meaning "to humiliate"<ref name=Tavernier/> and accordingly "kuru≈°" (hence "Cyrus") means "''humiliator'' (of the enemy in verbal contest)".<ref name=cyrusthename/>
